body: @nathanielmanistaatgoogle Should this be maximum message size?

@kpayson64: no. Perhaps the protocol should _also_ specify a maximum message size, but that's a separate concern.

Oh, but I think I see how the issue title might have been misread. Let me see if I can reword that...
so what is maximum message size for `grpc 1.0.0`?

@nickdul: as an implementation detail of gRPC 1.0.0, you'll start to see incorrect behavior around 4MiB. But for best results, [you should try to limit your messages to tens of kibibytes](https://github.com/grpc/grpc.github.io/issues/371).

> you'll start to see incorrect behavior around 4MiB

is this configurable or hardcoded limit in gRPC 1.0.0?

@nickdul: it depends on which programming language you're using. For gRPC Python 1.0.0 it's configurable by an undocumented intended-for-power-users channel argument on the client-side and it's not configurable on the server-side.
@nickdul: I don't happen to know but @ejona86 would.

> undocumented intended-for-power-users channel argument on the client-side

Hmm... I didn't really see this configuration being for "power users", although I guess it depends on your bar for "power users."

> it's not configurable on the server-side.

That sort of seems necessary. Is it is the works?

>  does max message length limitation exist for grpc-java (netty-based)?

Yes. v1.0.0-pre1 had this in its release notes:

> Reduced default max message size from 100 MiB to 4 MiB. `ManagedChannelBuilder.maxMessageSize()` and `ServerBuilder.maxMessageSize()` can override the default. Larger sizes are not a problem for grpc, but applications should be aware when they may receive large messages.

We really need a way to increase this limit. We have a lot of message types (>20+) that now require us to convert into a streaming/chunked format. It'll take us some time to do this so we'd really appreciate a stop-gap.

@proteneer, what language are you having trouble in?

Our intention is to support larger message sizes when it makes sense (so it doesn't even need to be a stop-gap), but to still encourage service developers to consider the impact of message sizes getting out-of-hand.

Python and Go. In particular the python server.

On Wednesday, September 21, 2016, Eric Anderson notifications@github.com
wrote:

> trouble in?

## 

Yutong Zhao

Go supports changing it on server-side (https://godoc.org/google.golang.org/grpc#MaxMsgSize). (It looks like the limit was not implemented client-side...)

Assigning to Nathaniel for Python.

@ejona86: note that this issue is not about @proteneer's immediate problem but rather something else entirely.

@proteneer: I think your need was recently addressed by @kpayson64 in [pull request 8137](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/pull/8137). If you are able to work from our master branch, what happens when you change

```
grpc.server(thread_pool)
```

in your code to

```
grpc.server(
    thread_pool,
    options=(('grpc.max_message_length', <a large integer of your choice>,),))
```

?
Thanks Nathaniel, and sorry for the thread hijack. We will test this out tomorrow. Will #8137 go into the v1.0.x branch?

This fix works. We cherry-picked the patch for the time being because we don't want to use master for production. Other than that we consider the issue resolved. Thanks @nathanielmanistaatgoogle and @ejona86 for the help.
"ChannelOptions.MaxMessageLength" not work in c# client (Grpc v1.1.0). The limit is about 4MB.
Is there a way to specify a max message size in node.js yet?

Yes, you can specify max message size in Node, using a format very similar to what was described for Python. The `Server` constructor takes a single argument, which is an object that contains these options. I should note that since this issue was opened, this particular option has been split into max size of sent messages and of received messages. So you would write something like this:

```js
new grpc.Server({'grpc.max_send_message_length': <large number>,
                 'grpc.max_receive_message_length': <large number>})
```

The `Client` constructors accept the same options in their third argument.
@murgatroid99 Thanks for the info. I discovered the same thing, but only after much digging through the source code.

I am having the issue for a php client interacting with a go server. Whereas the go server `MaxMsgSize` was set, I keep receiving this as message:
```
[null,{\"metadata\":[],\"code\":13,\"details\":\"Max message size exceeded\"}]
```

I tried adding `maxRequestMessageBytes` and `maxResponseMessageBytes` as options of the \Grpc\Channel, but I keep getting the same error. I strongly believe this is due to php client side error, because all the work is done serverside meaning the request was "accepted".

When looking into the code, I see the usage of the `timeout` option, but nowhere usage for any max_message_size option or similar.

here are values I looked for:

```
            "maxRequestMessageBytes" => 100<<20,
            "max_request_message_bytes" => 100<<20,
            "max_response_message_bytes" => 100<<20,
            "maxResponseMessageBytes" => 100<<20,
            "messageSize" => 100<<20,
            "message_size" => 100 << 20,
            "maxMessageSize" => 100<<20,
            "max_message_size" => 100<<20,
            "maxMessageSize" => 100<<20,
            "maxSize" => 100<<20,
            "max_size" => 100 <<20,
            "maxByteSize" => 100<<20,
            "max_byte_size" => 100<<20,
            "length" => 100<<20,
            "max_send_message_length" => 100<<20,
            "maxSendMessageLength" => 100<<20,
            "grpc.max_send_message_length" => 100<<20,
            "max_receive_message_length" => 100 << 20,
            "grpc.max_receive_message_length" => 100 << 20,
            "maxReceiveMessageLength" => 100 << 20,
            "maxMessageLength" => 100 <<20,
            "max_message_length" => 100 << 20,
```

ok the following seems to be working in PHP (for anyone striking into the issue):

set the following Channel option to a big value:
```
[
     "grpc.max_message_length": $bigvalue,
     ...
]
```
using the `v1.3.0` or more of grpc.

would make sense to harmonize this option across integrations (MaxMsgSize in go / grpc.max_message_length in php,  grpc.max_send_message_length in py or node ...)
Is there a way to set the message size on the client side in C++?
Having the same question as @marcofiocco

How to specify the max_receive_message_length in ruby? I tried by passing it as server_args while creating server as 
new(host_port: host_port, server_args: {:'grpc.max_receive_message_length' => 100 * 1024 * 1024})

But I still get the same error as GRPC::ResourceExhausted (8:to-be-sent trailing metadata size exceeds peer limit)
@KirtiChug, max message size is different from max header list size. I think you're looking for grpc.max_metadata_size instead.

@Possum3D I can't implement your solution in PHP.

I've got this code:
```
$buffer = 8 * 1024 * 1024 // 8Mb buffer
$server = 'localhost:1000';

$client = new MyGrpcService(
     $server,
     [
          'credentials' => Grpc\ChannelCredentials::createSsl($root, $key, $cert),
          'grpc.max_message_length' => $bufferSize
     ]
```

But it continues faillings with large grpc messages.

Any solution to this issue?

Thanks.
I need to increase the MaxMessageLength and I am using the grpcio python lib, can anyone show me the sample code for configuring it in python?

@Michael-Jing 
```python
MB = 1024 * 1024
GRPC_CHANNEL_OPTIONS = [('grpc.max_message_length', 64 * MB), ('grpc.max_receive_message_length', 64 * MB)]
channel = grpc.insecure_channel(api_url, options=settings.GRPC_CHANNEL_OPTIONS)
```
